text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.

6Nate English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Neil, and joining me is Rob.
Hello.
speaker: Rob

text: Today, we'll be discussing whether wearing high heel shoes is a fashion statement
or a sign of oppression.
And by that, I mean something you have to wear because someone has told you to.
Now, Neil, whatever style of shoe you choose to wear, it's good to polish them
and keep them looking shiny and new.
But one man from India called Vicrent Mahajan set the Guinness World Record
for polishing the most shoes.
Do you know how many pairs he polished in eight hours?
Was it a 151 pairs, b 251 pairs, or c 351 pairs?
Well, if it was me, it would be no more than one pair,
but as it's a world record, I'm going to go for 351 pairs.
Hopefully, you'll give me the answer later.
But let's focus now on high heels.
Yes, it's a style of shoe worn by women around the world.
But why do millions of people choose to walk on strange, still-like shoes?
Studies have suggested wearing high heels can lead to damage to the muscles and skeleton.
But despite this, they are worn to look professional in the workplace
or for glamour, a word to describe the quality of looking fashionable and attractive.
And of course, they're associated with female glamour,
which is something Tim Edwards, honorary fellow in sociology at the University of Leicester,
has been talking about on the BBC Radio 4 programme Thinking Allowed.
Here he is describing why he thinks that is.
Women's shoes in particular can have this kind of transformative or even magical quality.
They can do something for a woman.
And it's quite difficult to draw parallels quite like that with men,
as a sense in which it becomes something slightly otherworldly.
However, one views it as something which is an act of subordination or an act of empowerment,
etc.
There is a sense in which your experience is changed.
You are suddenly raised 3, 4, 5, 6, 6, 6.
It's higher, your balance is altered, your experience is transformed.
So he describes high heels as having a magical quality.
He uses the word transformative, meaning a great improvement or positive change,
so they transform or improve how someone looks.
Well, they do make you taller and that can make you feel more powerful or important.
Tim even said it becomes otherworldly,
Otherworldly is an adjective to describe belonging to an imaginary world rather than the real world â€“ it's magical or special.
speaker: Otherworldly

text: Magical shoes do sound otherworldly,
but Tim also mentioned that wearing high heels could be seen as an act of subordination.
That's making someone do something to give them less authority or power.
Well, I guess that's only if you're forced to wear them,
but there's another interesting point here.
Men don't have a style of footwear that can define them.
Yes, it's just sandals for you and sports trainers for me.
In fact, Tim Edwards says it's difficult to draw parallels with men's shoes
when you draw parallels between two distinct things.
It means you highlight the similarities.
But here he's saying it's difficult to find similarities.
Men have nothing special to wear on their feet.
Of course, there's nothing to stop men wearing high heels.
Although, personally, I don't think I'd be able to keep my balance.
But Tim Edwards suggests it will be viewed with suspicion.
Let's hear what he has to say.
I think the issue with men and footwear is that if you think of more contemporary culture,
men are a guy who wears overly flamboyant shoes or shoes
which are not black brown or flat.
It is viewed with a degree of suspicion,
either in terms of his sexuality or in terms of his work ethic,
or in terms of his general moral standard in other kinds of ways.
He says that if you don't wear a regular, ordinary black, brown, or flat style of shoe,
you might be viewed with suspicion.
Men who wear shoes that are flamboyant,
that's brightly coloured and that attract attention,
have their sexuality or their attitude to work judged.
He mentions someone's work ethic.
That's the belief that working hard is morally right.
A man who wears flamboyant shoes may have a different attitude to work.
Sounds like quite an old-fashioned view.
It does.
It does, and let's hope people don't judge you when you go out wearing your sandals and socks! But now, how about giving us the answer to the question you set earlier.
speaker: Neil

text: Now, how about giving us the answer to the question you said earlier?
Yes, I told you about Vikrant Mahajan,
who set the Guinness World Record for polishing the most shoes.
I asked if you knew how many pairs he polished in eight hours.
And I guessed 351 pairs. Come on, was I right?
speaker: Neil

text: Come on, was I right?
I'm afraid not Neil.
The answer was 251 pairs.
It's still quite a lot.
That's 502 individual shoes.
And I'm not sure if he actually got paid for doing it.
Right, let's polish up some of our English vocabulary and remind ourselves of some of the words we've discussed today, starting with oppression.
speaker: oppression

text: we've discussed today, starting with oppression.
Oppression is when you're forced to do something by someone more powerful.
We talked about glamour â€“ a word to describe the quality of looking fashionable and attractive.
speaker: glamour

text: Our next word was transformative â€“ meaning a great improvement or positive change.
speaker: transformative

text: Otherworldly is an adjective to describe belonging to an imaginary world,
rather than the real world.
It's magical or special.
We also discussed an act of subordination.
That's making someone do something to give them less authority or power.
To draw parallels is an idiom, meaning to highlight the similarities between two distinct things.
And we mentioned flamboyant.
And we mentioned flamboyant â€“ that describes someone or something brightly coloured and that attracts attention.
speaker: flamboyant

text: Finally, we talked about work ethic.
Finally, we talked about work ethic â€“Â that's the belief that working hard is morally right. Something that both Neil and I have!
speaker: work ethic â€“
